quiz.title: Unit 5: Perfect Competition (Quiz 3)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Graphical Analysis, Profit/Loss Calculation, Market Adjustments
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Graph Interpretation, Profit Rectangles, Short-Run Decisions, Long-Run Adjustments, Numerical MC/ATC/AVC Analysis

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market graph, if P > ATC at the profit-maximizing output, the firm’s economic profit is represented by:
options: The area between ATC and AVC up to Q*.
The area between P and ATC over the quantity produced.
The area under the MC curve up to Q*.
The area between P and AVC over the quantity produced.
questions.explanation: Economic profit per unit = P – ATC. Total profit = (P – ATC) × Q*, which is a rectangle.

questions.question: A perfectly competitive firm has the following cost data: at Q=10, MC = \$8, ATC = \$12, AVC = \$6. If market price is \$8, what should the firm do in the short run?
options: Produce 10 units and earn economic profit.
Produce where MR = MC and earn zero profit.
Produce 10 units and incur a loss but continue operating.
Shut down immediately.
questions.explanation: P = MC = \$8 at Q=10. P > AVC (\$6), so firm should produce and incur loss = (ATC – P) × Q = (\$12 – \$8) × 10 = \$40 loss, but it covers variable costs.

questions.question: If a perfectly competitive firm is producing where P = MC and P < ATC but P > AVC, the firm is:
options: Maximizing profit and should shut down.
Maximizing profit and should continue operating in the short run.
Not maximizing profit; should increase output.
Not maximizing profit; should decrease output.
questions.explanation: Profit max occurs at P = MC. If P < ATC but > AVC, firm incurs loss but continues operating in short run to cover variable costs.

questions.question: In a perfectly competitive market, the long-run industry supply curve will be horizontal if:
options: Input prices rise as industry expands.
Input prices fall as industry expands.
Input prices remain constant as industry expands.
Firms have identical cost structures.
questions.explanation: Constant-cost industry: input prices don’t change with industry output, so long-run supply is perfectly elastic (horizontal).

questions.question: A perfectly competitive firm has TC = 50 + 4Q + 0.5Q². What is its ATC when Q = 10?
If market demand increases in a constant-cost perfectly competitive industry, long-run equilibrium will feature:
options: Higher price and more firms.
Same price and more firms.
Lower price and fewer firms.
Same price and fewer firms.
questions.explanation: In a constant-cost industry, long-run supply is horizontal. Increased demand raises price short run, attracting entry until price returns to original min ATC — same price, more firms.

questions.question: A firm in perfect competition has AVC = 2Q and MC = 3Q. If market price is \$30, what is the profit-maximizing quantity?
When a perfectly competitive firm earns positive economic profit, which of the following will occur in the long run?
options: Market demand will increase.
Firm’s ATC curve will shift down.
New firms enter, market supply increases, price falls.
Existing firms expand output, lowering MC.
questions.explanation: Economic profit attracts entry, increasing market supply and lowering price until profit returns to zero.

questions.question: If a per-unit tax is imposed on firms in a perfectly competitive market, in the long run in a constant-cost industry:
options: Firms will all exit the market.
Price will rise by the full amount of the tax.
Firms will bear the entire tax burden.
Market output will remain unchanged.
questions.explanation: In constant-cost industry, long-run supply is horizontal, so a per-unit tax shifts supply up by tax amount, raising market price by full tax; zero profit is restored.

questions.question: A perfectly competitive firm’s total cost function is TC = 100 + Q². If market price is \$20, what is the firm’s short-run profit-maximizing output?
questions.explanation: MC = dTC/dQ = 2Q. Set P = MC: 20 = 2Q → Q = 10.

scoreMessages.90: Outstanding ability to analyze perfect competition numerically and graphically.
scoreMessages.70: Strong; review tax incidence and constant vs. increasing cost industries.
scoreMessages.50: Fair; revisit cost function math and graphical profit representation.
scoreMessages.0: Needs review: P=MC rule, shutdown condition, and long-run adjustments.
